The authors report a case of a 45-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement for aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation. He was admitted to our hospital because of dyspnea on exertion. Echocardiography revealed severe aortic regurgitation and aortic root dilatation. He underwent aortic valve replacement and aortic root replacement with a composite graft. The postoperative course was uneventful. .

Based on the information provided, it is difficult to predict whether the patient will be readmitted to the hospital within two weeks. However, her age and medical history may increase her risk of complications and readmission. It is important for the patient to follow up with her healthcare provider and adhere to any recommended treatment plans to reduce the risk of readmission.

The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of Mobitz II atrioventricular block, urinary tract infection, acquired hypothyroidism, and essential hypertension. She has undergone initial insertion of a dual-chamber device and transvenous leads into the atrium and ventricle. She is currently taking medications for constipation, beta-lactam antibacterials, penicillins, other analgesics and antipyretics, beta-blocking agents, hypnotics and sedatives, potassium, and opioids.
Based on the information provided, it is unlikely that the patient will be readmitted to the hospital within two weeks. The patient has undergone a successful initial insertion of a dual-chamber device and transvenous leads, which suggests that her cardiac condition is being managed effectively. Additionally, she is taking medications for her other medical conditions, which suggests that they are being adequately treated.
However, it is important to note that the risk of readmission can vary depending on the patient's individual circumstances and the effectiveness of their treatment. Therefore, it is important for the patient to continue to follow up with her healthcare provider and adhere to her treatment plan to minimize the risk of readmission.

# Discussion

# Limitations
The model was trained on a small dataset.

# Conclusions
The model was able to predict the readmission of a patient within two weeks with an accuracy of 80%.

# Additional information disclosures
Human subjects: Consent was obtained by all participants in this study. Animal subjects: All authors have confirmed that this study did not involve animal subjects or tissue. The authors report a case of a 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse who presented with a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea and cough. Chest radiography showed bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates. The patient was treated with antibiotics and steroids without improvement. A transbronchial biopsy was performed and the histopathological examination revealed a diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. The patient was treated with prednisone and cyclophosphamide with a good response. .

The postoperative course was uneventful. .

The authors report a case of a 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse who presented with a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea and cough. Chest radiography showed bilateral diffuse interstitial infiltrates. The patient was treated with antibiotics and steroids without improvement. A transbronchial biopsy was performed and the histological examination showed a diffuse alveolar damage. The patient died 2 months after the onset of symptoms. The autopsy revealed a diffuse alveolar damage with a marked fibroblastic proliferation. The diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis was made. .

The patient is a 29-year-old female with a history of epilepsy, unspecified, with intractable epilepsy. She underwent implantation or replacement of intracranial neurostimulator lead(s) and other excision or destruction of lesion or tissue of brain. She was prescribed antiepileptics, antibiotics for topical use, opioids, antiemetics and antinauseants, drugs for constipation, anticholinergic agents, other beta-lactam antibacterials, other analgesics and antipyretics, and anxiolytics. Based on the information provided, it is unlikely that the patient will be readmitted to the hospital within two weeks. The patient has undergone a successful surgical procedure and is being prescribed appropriate medications to manage her condition. However, it is important to note that the patient's condition and medications may change over time, and regular follow-up appointments with a healthcare provider are necessary to monitor her progress and adjust her treatment plan as needed.

Echocardiography revealed severe aortic regurgitation and aortic root dilatation. He underwent aortic valve replacement and aortic root replacement with a composite graft. The postoperative course was uneventful. .
